summary: Email correspondence between court personnel regarding obtaining a stamped copy of the signed arrest warrant and indictment for Ghislaine Maxwell. The email chain includes the signed warrant and indictment documents from late June 2020.

persons.name: Danny Ortiz
persons.context: Recipient of email correspondence regarding the Maxwell arrest warrant, appears to be court staff at the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Vincent Babino
persons.context: Court clerk at the United States District Court Southern District of New York who sent an email requesting a stamped copy of the Maxwell warrant application.

persons.name: Katharine Parker
persons.context: Judge who signed the Maxwell arrest warrant and indictment on June 30, 2020, as indicated in the email correspondence.

connections.description: Judge Parker sent signed warrant documents to court clerk Danny Ortiz as part of court procedures.
Court clerks communicating about obtaining stamped copies of legal documents for the Maxwell case.

events.title: Maxwell Warrant Signed
events.description: Judge Katharine Parker signed the arrest warrant and indictment for Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Warrant Copy Request
events.description: Court clerk Vincent Babino requests a stamped copy of the Maxwell warrant application with a mag number.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York, 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY 10007
I St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Judge Katharine Parker signed the arrest warrant and indictment for Ghislaine Maxwell on June 30, 2020.
The email correspondence shows court procedures for processing and stamping arrest warrants in the Southern District of New York.
Attachments included Maxwell's signed indictment, arrest warrant, and GPS monitoring application documents.
The document confirms the timing of legal proceedings against Ghislaine Maxwell in July 2020.
Court clerks were coordinating to obtain properly stamped versions of the warrant with magistrate numbers.
